title: Legendre form
summary: In mathematics, the Legendre forms of elliptic integrals are a canonical set of three elliptic integrals to which all others may be reduced. Legendre chose the name elliptic integrals because[1] the second kind gives the arc length of an ellipse of unit semi-major axis and eccentricity k {\displaystyle \scriptstyle {k}} (the ellipse being defined parametrically by x = 1 − k 2 cos ⁡ ( t ) {\displaystyle \scriptstyle {x={\sqrt {1-k^{2}}}\cos(t)}} , y = sin ⁡ ( t ) {\displaystyle \scriptstyle {y=\sin(t)}} ).
